title: Welcome & get ready for the course
text:
Learning Goals (for the course)


Be able to use a common set of data science tools (R, RStudio IDE, Git, GitHub, tidyverse, Quarto) to illustrate and communicate the results of data analysis projects.
Learn to use the Quarto file format and the RStudio IDE visual editing mode to produce documents with citations, footnotes, cross-references, figures, and tables.
Be able to design a questionnaire to collect information that can be analysed to answer a waste-related research question that is relevant for Zurich.
Understand the main challenges associated with managing different types of waste, and how they differ between Europe and Africa.

Version Control with Git and GitHub
A way to share files with others, so they can:

download
re-use
contribute

You can view the history of files, and jump back in time to any point.

title: Welcome & get ready for the course
text: Why is it useful?

title: Welcome & get ready for the course
text:
Git and GitHub












Git is a software for version control
Created in 2005
Popular among programmers collaboratively developing code
Tracks changes in a set of files (directory/folder/repository)












GitHub is a hosting platform for version control using Git
Launched in 2008, aquired by Microsoft in in 2018, Microsoft for US$ 7.5 billion

100 million Users (20.5 in 2022 alone) (October, 2023)

Social media for software developers

Performance assessment

End-of-semester exam: 50 points
Compulsory continuous performance assessment: 50 points, of which

Homework assignments: 20 points (n = 10)
Capstone project: 30 points, of which

Technical parts of submitted report: 20 points (we will communicate what we expect)
Intellectual framing of results: 10 points (we will communicate what we expect)

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
Tipps for search engines

Use actionable verbs that describe what you want to do
Be specific
Add R to the search query
Add the name of the R package name to the search query
Scroll through the top 5 results (don‚Äôt just pick the first)

Example: ‚ÄúHow to remove a legend from a plot in R ggplot2‚Äù

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
Stack Overflow



What is it?

The biggest support network for (coding) problems
Can be intimidating at first
Up-vote system




Workflow

First, briefly read the question that was posted
Then, read the answer marked as ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù
Then, read one or two more answers with high votes
Then, check out the ‚ÄúLinked‚Äù posts
Always give credit for the solution

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
Learning Objectives (for this week)


Learners can identify four components of a Quarto file (YAML, code chunk, R code, markdown).
Learners can list the six elements of the data science lifecycle.
Learners can describe the four main aesthetic mappings that can be used to visualise data using the ggplot2 R Package.
Learners can control the colour scaling applied to a plot using colour as an aesthetic mapping.
Learners can compare three different geoms (bar/col, histogram, point) and their use case.

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
Deep End





via GIPHY

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
-

Add notes

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
-


First you must import your data into R. This typically means that you take data stored:


in a file
in a database,
or web application, and load it into R.


If you can get your data into R, you can do data science on it!

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
-


Once you‚Äôve imported your data, it is a good idea to tidy it.
This means to get it into a structure that lets you focus on the questions about your data and not the format it needs to be in
This is the step where we spend by far the biggest amount of our time.
It has been estimated that we spend about 80% of our time with cleaning and tidying data, so that we can use it fo our analyses.
In my courses you will learn how to structure your data in a tidy format as you collect it, and before you import it. A highly underestimated skill.

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
-


Once your data is tidy, a common first step is to transform it.
This includes


narrowing in on what interests you (like all people without toilets in one district, or all data from last year)
creating new variables from existing (like toilet density, as in number of people per toilet)
calculating summary statistics (like counts or the mean)

Together, tidying and transforming are called wrangling, because getting your data in a form that‚Äôs natural to work with often feels like a fight!

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
-


Once you have tidy data with the variables you need, there are two main engines of knowledge generation:


visualization
and modelling.


These have complementary strengths and weaknesses so any real analysis will iterate between them many times.
Visualization is a fundamentally human activity. A good visualization will show you things that you did not expect, or raise new questions about the data.

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
-


Models are complementary tools to visualization. Once you have made your questions sufficiently precise, you can use a model to answer them.
In my courses, they play a very small part, but I am confident that you will be able to enhance your knowledge on modelling once you understand the basic principles of using the R lanuage.

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
-


The last step of data science is communication, an absolutely critical part of any data analysis project.
It doesn‚Äôt matter how well your models and visualization have led you to understand the data, unless you can also communicate your results to others.
And this is a part where R has become really strong.

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
R Package ggplot2



ggplot2 is tidyverse‚Äôs data visualization package
gg in ggplot2 stands for Grammar of Graphics
Inspired by the book Grammar of Graphics by Leland Wilkinson
Documentation: https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/
Book: https://ggplot2-book.org






Slide adapted from datasciencebox.org

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
Code structure

ggplot() is the main function in ggplot2
Plots are constructed in layers
Structure of the code for plots can be summarized as


ggplot(data = [dataset], 
       mapping = aes(x = [x-variable], 
                     y = [y-variable])) +
  geom_xxx() +
  other options

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
Code structure

ggplot()

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
Code structure

ggplot(data = gapminder)

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
Code structure

ggplot(data = gapminder,
       mapping = aes())

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
Code structure

ggplot(data = gapminder,
       mapping = aes(x = continent,
                     y = lifeExp))

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
Code structure

ggplot(data = gapminder,
       mapping = aes(x = continent,
                     y = lifeExp)) +
  geom_boxplot()

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
Code structure

ggplot(data = gapminder,
       mapping = aes(x = continent,
                     y = lifeExp)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_minimal()

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
section: Poll 1: What does the thick line inside the box of a boxplot represent?
text:
Poll 1: What does the thick line inside the box of a boxplot represent?



I don‚Äôt know
the mean of the observations
the middle of the box
the median of the observations

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
section: Poll 2: What percentage of observations are contained inside the box of a boxplot (interquartile range)?
text:
Poll 2: What percentage of observations are contained inside the box of a boxplot (interquartile range)?



I don‚Äôt know
25%
depends on the median
50%

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
section: Poll 3: What is the median of a set of observations?
text:
Poll 3: What is the median of a set of observations?

I don‚Äôt know
The median is the most frequently occurring value in a dataset.
The median is the sum of all values in a dataset divided by the number of observations.
The median is the point above and below which half (50%) of the observations falls.

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
section: Poll 4: If you have the values: 1, 2, 3, and 10: which statistical measure best represents the ‚Äútrue‚Äù value?
text:
Poll 4: If you have the values: 1, 2, 3, and 10: which statistical measure best represents the ‚Äútrue‚Äù value?

I don‚Äôt know
The maximum
The standard deviation
The median

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
Boxplot, explained


Figure¬†1: Diagram depicting how a boxplot is created.

Image taken from: https://r4ds.hadley.nz/data-visualize#fig-eda-boxplot



A box that indicates the range of the middle half of the data, a distance known as the interquartile range (IQR), stretching from the 25th percentile of the distribution to the 75th percentile.
In the middle of the box is a line that displays the median, i.e.¬†50th percentile, of the distribution.
These three lines give you a sense of the spread of the distribution and whether or not the distribution is symmetric about the median or skewed to one side.
Visual points that display observations that fall more than 1.5 times the IQR from either edge of the box. These outlying points are unusual so are plotted individually.
A line (or whisker) that extends from each end of the box and goes to the farthest non-outlier point in the distribution.

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
Types of variables



numerical
discrete variables

non-negative
whole numbers
e.g.¬†number of students, roll of a dice

continuous variables

infinite number of values
also dates and times
e.g.¬†length, weight, size


non-numerical
categorical variables

finite number of values
distinct groups (e.g.¬†EU countries, continents)
ordinal if levels have natural ordering (e.g.¬†week days, school grades)

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
Histogram

for visualizing distribution of continuous (numerical) variables


ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = body_mass_g)) +
  geom_histogram()

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
Barplot

for visualizing distribution of categorical (non-numerical) variables


ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = species)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization
text:
Scatterplot

for visualizing relationships between two continuous (numerical) variables


ggplot(data = gapminder_2007,
       mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap,
                     y = lifeExp,
                     size = pop,
                     color = continent)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_color_colorblind() +
  theme_minimal()

title: Data science lifecycle & Exploratory data analysis using visualization

Your turn: md-02-exercises

Open the rbtl-fs25 workspace for the course.
In the File Manager in the bottom right window, locate the md-02c-make-a-plot.qmd file and click on it to open it in the top left window.
Follow instructions in the file
